title: Ticket #3289: Grid manager prematurely destroys keypairs.
description:
The GM_DELETE state in ec2job.cpp attempts to destroy the keypair created earlier in the job's lifecycle. This state unconditionally follows GM_HOLD, which is entered when, for instance, a network burp prevents GM_PROBE_JOB from discovering the state of a (previously noted to be) running instance.

It may be OK to destroy the keypair -- if doing so doesn't destroy the instance's copy of the key, because if the job isn't still running by the time we get back to it, we can just make another one for resubmission -- but we shouldn't delete the user's copy of the private key until we know that the instance is gone, because otherwise they can't log in to it.

While we could destroy the keypair in GM_SAVE_INSTANCE_ID -- under the condition above, since the instance has started running and has its own undeletable copy of the public key -- it won't hurt anything to leave the keypair active longer, until, say, GM_DELETE.

Checking in GM_DELETE to see if the job is REMOVED or COMPLETED should suffice to only delete the user's key until we know the instance is terminated. (If we have a problem terminating the instance when the user removes the job, we'll go into HOLD instead.) This is probably the smallest code change that will resolve the problem.

We also need to make sure that we handle recovering a job whose instance has a destroyed keypair.
remarks:
2012-Oct-25 17:52:16 by johnkn:
Bulk change of target version from v070806 to v070807 using ./ticket-target-mover.

2012-Nov-26 16:57:54 by tlmiller:
We set ATTR_EC2_KEY_PAIR in the job ad in GM_SAVE_CLIENT_TOKEN, and check for it on startup, so we won't recreate it unnecessarily. Otherwise, recovery ignores the keypair entirely.

2012-Nov-27 11:54:21 by tlmiller:
The current fix opens up a way to leave the key on disk after the job's been removed. (condor_hold no longer deletes the key; on a condor_rm of a held job, the grid manager doesn't enter the state machine, so the key isn't never deleted.) This could be fixed with cleverness about when not to remove the key (only remove on condor_hold or periodic_hold?) or maybe better by adjusting the grid manager's logic to check for a key on disk for a REMOVED or COMPLETED job.
